instruction: [INST] Analyze this file to learn MacBook motherboard repair. The 'definitions' section explains key technical terms. The 'threads' section contains real-world repair discussions. Use both sections to understand and learn how to troubleshoot MacBook issues. Posts from username 'larossmann' , 'dukefawks' , and '2informaticos' are posts from trusted experts.[/INST]

definitions.A1989: What is A1989? A1989 is a model number for a 13 inch size MacBook Pro Retina from years 2018, 2019 with EMC 3124, that may contain one of these boards depending on the year & configuration: 820-00850..
definitions.820-00850: What is 820-00850? a LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER.
definitions.CD3215: What is CD3215? This is a USB-C muxing chip responsible for USB-C communication with devices such as the laptop charger. The most common issue this chip is involved in is when a Macbook wonâ€™t charge or the charger is stuck at 5v instead of going to 20v..
definitions.PPBUS_G3H: What is PPBUS_G3H? Main system power rail that charges the battery, or is power from the battery, that everything else is powered from. .
definitions.PP3V3_UPC_XB_LDO: What is PP3V3_UPC_XB_LDO? PP3V3_UPC_XB_LDO is an LDO coming out of the CD3215 USB-C muxing/charging chip. This can be shorted to ground by the capacitor on its line, and when this happens, the chip can stop functioning which causes the charger to not turn on..
definitions.PP3V3_UPC_XA_LDO: What is PP3V3_UPC_XA_LDO? PP3V3_UPC_XA_LDO is an LDO coming out of the CD3215 USB-C muxing chip. When this is missing, either a capacitor on the line has shorted, PP3V3_G3H is missing, or the CD3215 is bad..
definitions.PP1V1_UPC_XB_LDO_BMC: What is PP1V1_UPC_XB_LDO_BMC? PP1V1_UPC_XB_LDO is an LDO coming out of the CD3215 USB-C muxing/charging chip. This can be shorted to ground by the capacitor on its line, and when this happens, the chip can stop functioning which causes the charger to not turn on. This can also be missing if the CD3215 chip itself is bad..
definitions.PP1V8_UPC_XB_LDOD: What is PP1V8_UPC_XB_LDOD? PP3V3_UPC_XB_LDO is an LDO coming out of the CD3215 USB-C muxing chip. When this is missing, either a capacitor on the line has shorted, PP3V3_G3H is missing, or the CD3215 is bad..
definitions.PP1V1_UPC_XA_LDO_BMC: What is PP1V1_UPC_XA_LDO_BMC? PP1V1_UPC_XA_LDO is an LDO coming out of the CD3215 USB-C muxing chip. When this is missing, either a capacitor on the line has shorted, PP3V3_G3H is missing, or the CD3215 is bad..
definitions.PP1V8_UPC_XB_LDOA: What is PP1V8_UPC_XB_LDOA? This is an LDO coming out of the CD3215 USB-C muxing/charging chip. This can be shorted to ground by the capacitor on its line, and when this happens, the chip can stop functioning which causes the charger to not turn on. This can also be missing if the CD3215 chip itself is bad. Each CD3215 in the system needs to be functioning in order for any of them to speak to the charger and negotiate receiving 20v from the charger rather than the default 5v that a USB-C charger puts out before communicating with the system. .
definitions.PP3V3_UPC_TA_LDO: What is PP3V3_UPC_TA_LDO? PP3V3_UPC_TA_LDO is an LDO coming out of the CD3215 USB-C muxing chip. When this is missing, either a capacitor on the line has shorted, PP3V3_G3H is missing, or the CD3215 is bad..
definitions.USBC_XA_CC2: What is USBC_XA_CC2? USBC_XA_CC2 is a line between the USB-C muxing chip such as the CD3217 or CD3215 and the USB-C charger. Communication must happen on this line in order for the USB-C charger to put out 20v..
definitions.USBC_XB_CC1: What is USBC_XB_CC1? USBC_XB_CC1 is a line between the USB-C muxing chip such as the CD3217 or CD3215 and the USB-C charger. Communication must happen on this line in order for the USB-C charger to put out 20v..
definitions.USBC_XB_CC2: What is USBC_XB_CC2? USBC_XB_CC2 is a line between the USB-C muxing chip such as the CD3217 or CD3215 and the USB-C charger. Communication must happen on this line in order for the USB-C charger to put out 20v..
definitions.USBC_TB_CC2: What is USBC_TB_CC2? USBC_TB_CC2 is a line between the USB-C muxing chip such as the CD3217 or CD3215 and the USB-C charger. Communication must happen on this line in order for the USB-C charger to put out 20v..

threads.title: <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1989</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00850</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-07 no power
threads.message:
Hi,

I have an <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1989</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00850</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-07, that had a bit of liquid contact in the Keyboard conector area (J6700) and near QB631 area is a bit oxidated, with no power.

It puls 5V from ampeter in all USB-C ports, and around 0.05A

<SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL> = 12.25V (board alone)

I think all diode values of <CHIP>CD3215</CHIP> ships are ok.

UB400:
<SIGNAL>PP1V1_UPC_TB_LDO_BMC</SIGNAL> = 0.527
<SIGNAL>PP1V8_UPC_TB_LDOD</SIGNAL> = 0.491
<SIGNAL>PP1V8_UPC_TB_LDOA</SIGNAL> = 0.532
<SIGNAL>PP3V3_UPC_TB_LDO</SIGNAL> = 0.505
<SIGNAL>USBC_TB_CC1</SIGNAL> = 0.600
<SIGNAL>USBC_TB_CC2</SIGNAL> = 0.605

<CHIP>U3200</CHIP>:
<SIGNAL>PP1V1_UPC_XB_LDO_BMC</SIGNAL> = 0.529
<SIGNAL>PP1V8_UPC_XB_LDOD</SIGNAL> = 0.495
<SIGNAL>PP1V8_UPC_XB_LDOA</SIGNAL> = 0.536
<SIGNAL>PP3V3_TBT_X_SX</SIGNAL> = 0.535
<SIGNAL>PP3V3_UPC_XB_LDO</SIGNAL> = 0.507
<SIGNAL>USBC_XB_CC1</SIGNAL> = 0.602
<SIGNAL>USBC_XB_CC2</SIGNAL> = 0.606

<CHIP>U3100</CHIP>:
<SIGNAL>PP1V1_UPC_XA_LDO_BMC</SIGNAL> = 0.483
<SIGNAL>PP1V8_UPC_XA_LDOD</SIGNAL> = 0.457
<SIGNAL>PP1V8_UPC_XA_LDOA</SIGNAL> = 0.491
<SIGNAL>PP3V3_TBT_X_SX</SIGNAL> = 0.535
<SIGNAL>PP3V3_UPC_XA_LDO</SIGNAL> = 0.506
<SIGNAL>USBC_XA_CC1</SIGNAL> = 0.595
<SIGNAL>USBC_XA_CC2</SIGNAL> = 0.593

UB300:
<SIGNAL>PP1V1_UPC_TA_LDO_BMC</SIGNAL> = 0.485
<SIGNAL>PP1V8_UPC_TA_LDOD</SIGNAL> = 0.459
<SIGNAL>PP1V8_UPC_TA_LDOA</SIGNAL> = 0493
<SIGNAL>PP3V3_TBT_T_SX</SIGNAL> = 0.535
<SIGNAL>PP3V3_UPC_TA_LDO</SIGNAL> = 0.505
<SIGNAL>USBC_TA_CC1</SIGNAL> = 0.597
<SIGNAL>USBC_TA_CC2</SIGNAL> = 0.601

Can you help?

threads.title: <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1989</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00850</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-07 no power
threads.message:
Tested with 87W charger and battery, both connected?
What about <SIGNAL>UPC_I2C_INT_L</SIGNAL>?

threads.title: <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1989</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00850</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-07 no power
threads.message:
Hi,

Yes, I've tested it with an 90W original charger, with battery connected.

<SIGNAL>UPC_I2C_INT_L</SIGNAL> = 0.491

threads.title: <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1989</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00850</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-07 no power
threads.message:
Something pulls down that signal.
You can try removing/replacing <CHIP>CD3215</CHIP> chips one by one.

threads.title: <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1989</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00850</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-07 no power
threads.message:
I've replaced all <CHIP>CD3215</CHIP> (one by one) but same result.

4.99V and 0.03A in all ports

threads.title: <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1989</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00850</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-07 no power
threads.message:
Did you check mentioned signal each time you've removed a <CHIP>CD3215</CHIP> chip?
Tried DFU?

threads.title: <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1989</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00850</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-07 no power
threads.message:
Hi,

<SIGNAL>UPC_I2C_INT_L</SIGNAL> stays always the same readings.

I've tried DFU now, but with same result.

However, I notice that <TRANSISTOR>Q3451</TRANSISTOR> had a small dot, that seamed to be burnt (not sure) and so I've replaced it, and <SIGNAL>SAVE_XB_CC1_B</SIGNAL> and <SIGNAL>SAVE_XB_CC2_B</SIGNAL> have OL in diode reading and were the same values before replacing <TRANSISTOR>Q3451</TRANSISTOR>. Is that normal?

threads.title: <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1989</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00850</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-07 no power
<MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1989</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00850</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-07 no power
threads.message:
Hi.

All readings are the same in <TRANSISTOR>Q3431</TRANSISTOR>

However, I notice that all QB651, QB631, <TRANSISTOR>Q3451</TRANSISTOR> and <TRANSISTOR>Q3431</TRANSISTOR> had a small burnt mark. I have replaced them all, but i have the same result, and the same diode readings in all of them.

I also notice something strange witch is (i'll try to explain):

When I conect the charger on the UB400 port, I get 0.050 ~ 0.080V on FB200 (UB300 fuse), and slowly drops to 0V. That only happends on this port.

threads.title: <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1989</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00850</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-07 no power
threads.message: <SIGNAL>UPC_I2C_INT_L</SIGNAL> must go high, to allow switching to 20V.

threads.title: <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1989</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00850</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-07 no power
threads.message: Can it be <CHIP>U3900</CHIP>? Should I reball it?

threads.title: <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1989</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00850</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-07 no power
threads.message:
Hi,

I've replaced all <CHIP>CD3215</CHIP> again, and <SIGNAL>UPC_I2C_INT_L</SIGNAL> always stayed low (on every time). Can it be T2 chip pulling it down?

What else can i check?

threads.title: <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1989</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00850</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-07 no power
threads.message:
That is an option too.
Be sure no corrosion on the J3000 and JB200 pads.

threads.title: <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1989</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00850</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-07 no power
threads.message:
There is no corrosion on J3000 and JB200 pads.

Is there anything else I can do?

threads.title: <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1989</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00850</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-07 no power
threads.message:
Any <CHIP>CD3215</CHIP> chip can pull down the signal, if detects a problem on its area.
So you may have damaged component, trace, corrosion, etc.

Does the machine complete DFU, or ends with error?
